column1: San Jose (; Spanish: [saŋ xoˈse]; Spanish for '"Saint Joseph"')
column2: officially the City of San José
column3: is the cultural
column4: financial
column5: and political center of Silicon Valley and the largest city in Northern California
column6: by both population and area.

column4: it is the third-most populous city in California (after Los Angeles and San Diego) and the tenth-most populous in the United States. Located in the center of the Santa Clara Valley
column5: on the southern shore of San Francisco Bay
column6: San Jose covers an area of 179.97 square miles (466.1 km2). San Jose is the county seat of Santa Clara County
column7: the most affluent county in California and one of the most affluent counties in the United States. San Jose is the main component of the San Jose–Sunnyvale–Santa Clara Metropolitan Statistical Area
column8: with an estimated population of around 2 million residents in 2018. It is also the most populous city in both the San Francisco Bay Area and the San Jose-San Francisco-Oakland Combined Statistical Area
column9: which contain 7.7 million and 8.7 million people respectively.San Jose is notable as a center of innovation
column10: for its affluence
column11: Mediterranean climate
column12: and extremely high cost of living. Its location within the booming high tech industry as a cultural
column13: political
column14: and economic center has earned the city the nickname "Capital of Silicon Valley". San Jose is one of the wealthiest major cities in the United States and the world
column15: and has the third-highest GDP per capita in the world (after Zürich
column18: according to the Brookings Institution. The San Jose Metropolitan Area has the most millionaires and the most billionaires in the United States per capita. With a median home price of $1
column21: San Jose has the most expensive housing market in the country and the fifth most expensive housing market in the world
column22: according to the 2017 Demographia International Housing Affordability Survey. Major global tech companies including Cisco Systems
column30: and Zoom maintain their headquarters in San Jose
column31: in the center of Silicon Valley.

column1: Before the arrival of the Spanish
column2: the area around San Jose was inhabited by the Tamien nation of the Ohlone peoples of California. San Jose was founded on November 29
column4: as the Pueblo de San José de Guadalupe
column5: the first city founded in the Californias. It then became a part of Mexico in 1821 after the Mexican War of Independence. Following the American Conquest of California during the Mexican–American War

The rapid growth of the high-technology and electronics industries further accelerated the transition from an agricultural center to an urbanized metropolitan area. Results of the 1990 U.S. Census indicated that San Jose had officially surpassed San Francisco as the most populous city in Northern California. By the 1990s

column22: the "City of San José" in the text uses the mark but the "City of San Jose" logo image does not.San Jose's position in Silicon Valley triggered further economic and population growth. Results from the 1990 U.S. Census indicated that San Jose surpassed San Francisco as the most populous city in the Bay Area for the first time. This growth led to the highest housing-cost increase in the nation
column23: 936% between 1976 and 2001. Efforts to increase density continued into the 1990s when an update of the 1974 urban plan kept the urban growth boundaries intact and voters rejected a ballot measure to ease development restrictions in the foothills. Sixty percent of the housing built in San Jose since 1980 and over three-quarters of the housing built since 2000 have been multifamily structures
column24: reflecting a political propensity toward Smart Growth planning principles.

column14: was the world's first radio station with scheduled programming targeted at a general audience. The station became the first to broadcast music in 1910. column1: Because the downtown area is in the flight path to nearby Mineta San Jose International Airport (also evidenced in the above panoramic)
column2: there is a height limit for buildings in the downtown area
column3: which is underneath the final approach corridor to the airport. The height limit is dictated by local ordinances
column4: driven by the distance from the runway and a slope defined by Federal Aviation Administration regulations. Core downtown buildings are limited to approximately 300 feet (91 m) but can get taller farther from the airport.There has been broad criticism over the past few decades of the city's architecture. Citizens have complained that San Jose is lacking in aesthetically pleasing architectural styles. Blame for this lack of architectural "beauty" can be assigned to the re-development of the downtown area from the 1950s onward
column5: in which whole blocks of historic commercial and residential structures were demolished. Exceptions to this include the Downtown Historic District
column6: the Hotel De Anza
column7: and the Hotel Sainte Claire
column8: both of which are listed in the National Register of Historic Places for their architectural and historical significance.

column1: Early public art included a statue of Quetzalcoatl (the plumed serpent) downtown
column2: controversial in its planning because some called it pagan
column3: and controversial in its implementation because many felt that the final statue by Robert Graham did not look like a winged serpent
column4: and was more noted for its expense than its aesthetics. Locals joked that the statue resembles a pile of feces.A statue of Thomas Fallon also met strong resistance from those who called him largely responsible for the decimation of early native populations. Chicano/Latino activists protested because he had captured San Jose by military force in the Mexican–American War (1846). They also protested the perceived "repression" of historic documents detailing Fallon's orders expelling many of the city's Californio (early Spanish/Mexican/Mestizo) residents. In October 1991 protests at Columbus Day and Dia de la Raza celebrations stalled than plan
column5: and the statue was stored in a warehouse in Oakland for more than a decade. The statue returned in 2002 to a less conspicuous location: Pellier Park
column6: a small triangular patch at the merge of West Julian and West St. James streets.In 2001
column7: the city-sponsored SharkByte
column8: an exhibit of decorated sharks based on the mascot of the hockey team
column10: and modeled after Chicago's display of decorated cows. Large models of sharks decorated in clever
column11: colorful
column12: or creative ways by local artists were displayed for months at dozens of locations around the city. After the exhibition
column13: the sharks were auctioned off for charity.

column2: Adobe Systems commissioned an art installation titled San Jose Semaphore by Ben Rubin
column3: at the top of its headquarters building. Semaphore is composed of four LED discs which "rotate" to transmit a message. The content remained a mystery until it was deciphered in August 2007. The visual art installation is supplemented with an audio track
column4: transmitted from the building on a low-power AM station. The audio track provides clues to decode the message being transmitted.

column1: San Jose is a charter city under California law
column2: giving it the power to enact local ordinances that may conflict with state law
column3: within the limits provided by the charter. The city has a council-manager government with a city manager nominated by the mayor and elected by the city council.

column1: The San Jose City Council is made up of ten council members elected by district
column2: and a mayor elected by the entire city. During city council meetings
column3: the mayor presides
column4: and all eleven members can vote on any issue. The mayor has no veto powers. Council members and the mayor are elected to four-year terms; the even-numbered district council members beginning in 1994; the mayor and the odd-numbered district council members beginning in 1996.  Each council member represents approximately 100

column1: Council members and the mayor are limited to two successive terms in office
column2: although a council member that has reached the term limit can be elected mayor
column3: and vice versa. The council elects a vice-mayor from the members of the council at the second meeting of the year following a council election. This council member acts as mayor during the temporary absence of the mayor
column4: but does not succeed to the mayor's office upon a vacancy.The City Manager is the chief administrative officer of the city
column5: and must present an annual budget for approval by the city council. When the office is vacant
column6: the Mayor proposes a candidate for City Manager
column7: subject to council approval. The council appoints the Manager for an indefinite term
column8: and may at any time remove the manager
column9: or the electorate may remove the manager through a recall election. Other city officers directly appointed by the council include the City Attorney
column10: City Auditor
column11: City Clerk
column12: and Independent Police Auditor. Like all cities and counties in the state
column13: San Jose has representation in the state legislature.

column1: Like all California cities except San Francisco

column3: plus parts of the surrounding unincorporated county land
column4: where San Jose can
column6: prevent development of fringe areas to concentrate city growth closer to the city's core. The LAFCO also defines a subset of the Sphere as an 'Urban Service Area' (indicated by the red line in the map)
column7: effectively limiting development to areas where urban infrastructure (sewers

column5: crime levels had fallen significantly after rising in the 1980s. Today it is no longer ranked as one of the safest cities in the country with a population over 1

column1: Like other American cities built mostly after World War II
column2: San Jose is highly automobile-dependent
column3: with 76 percent of residents driving alone to work and 12 percent carpooling in 2017. The city set an ambitious goal to shift motorized trips to walking

column6: but has so far failed to make progress towards these goals. In 2018 the city extended these goals to 2050 with its San Jose Climate Smart plan
column7: when driving alone to work is expected to drop to just 12 percent and transit is to leap to 35 percent of commute trips and walking and bicycling (combined) also to 35 percent of commute trips.

column1: Central San Jose has seen a gradual expansion of bike lanes over the past decade
column2: which now comprise a network of car-traffic-separated and buffered bike lanes. San Jose Bike Party is a volunteer-run monthly social cycling event that attracts up to 1
column3: 000 participants during summer months to "build community through bicycling". Unfortunately
column4: fewer than one percent of city residents ride bicycles to work as their primary mode of transportation
column5: a statistic unchanged in the past ten years. Typically
column6: between 3 and 5 residents are struck and killed by car drivers while bicycling on San Jose streets each year.

column1: San Jose is crossed by several major regional off-street paved trails
column2: most notably the Guadalupe River Trail
column3: Los Gatos Creek Trail
column4: and Coyote Creek Trail. These trails extend from near downtown San Jose for dozens of miles to the north and south
column5: and are connected with each other via bicycle routes of varying quality. The city is planning to construct new trail extensions in the coming years including the Three Creeks Trail and San Tomas Aquino Creek Trail.
